description: Back-formation from defenestration, from Latin de- (“out”) + fenestra (“window”).

verbs.description: defenestrate (third-person singular simple present defenestrates, present participle defenestrating, simple past and past participle defenestrated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To eject or throw (someone or something) from or through a window.
examples: I defenestrated a clock to see if time flies!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw out; to remove or dismiss (someone) from a position of power or authority.
examples: The cultural historians of science 'feel the need to defenestrate science, or at least take it off its pedestal' (Pumfrey. Rossi & Slawinski 1991. p. 3).

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive, humorous, slang) To remove a Windows operating system from a computer.
examples: This posting was written on a Windows 95 PC,
